sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: High-stakes diplomacy in Moscow. French President Macron sits down with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin in a bid to find a solution to the crisis in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: German Chancellor Scholz makes his Washington debut meeting President Biden for more talks on Ukraine, while in Kiev, European foreign ministers gather.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Spotify says it will stand by American podcaster Joe Rogan despite anger over his previous racist remarks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And age is just a number at the Winter Olympics, as 15-year-old figure skater Kamila Valieva becomes the first woman to land a quadruple, and 41 year old Yoann Claret takes the title as the oldest medalist in alpine skiing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey, good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: President Emmanuel Macron has held talks with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin in Moscow in an effort to try and ease tensions with Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The French president is on a diplomatic push to try and avoid conflicts starting between Russia and Ukraine. Macron will go to Kiev on Tuesday to meet President Volodymyr Zelensky.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Ahead of the meeting, the Kremlin downplayed the hopes of reaching any solution. President Macron said he was reasonably optimistic but didn't believe in spontaneous miracles.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, President Macron has spoken with the Russian president three times by phone in recent days, as well as talking to Joe Biden ahead of his trip to Moscow to plan a coordinated approach.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Let's get the view from our Russia analyst Galina Polonskaya, who joins me now. Good evening to you, Galina. Good to see you. To begin with, President Macron is the one who traveled to speak to President Vladimir Putin in Moscow. What do you think he'll want to take away?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Something that he can then present to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy when he goes there on Tuesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Helena. Well, exactly. No spontaneous miracles are expected by Emmanuel Macron himself, but I think that the best outcome that he could bring to President Zelenskyy tomorrow in Kyiv is the agreement of Vladimir Putin to bring the level of the nomad reform talks to the higher level, at least to the level of the foreign ministers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is the only format which exists right now where Ukraine and Russia are actually sitting together and talking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The political advisors restarted this process recently.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And, of course, the goal of Emmanuel Macron is to push forward and to see Ukraine and Russia at the table of negotiations. But as he said to the journalists, he does not expect any miracles. So he does not believe that he will bring back the news that Russia is pulling its troops away from the Ukrainian border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: He, however, wants to put at the table today, while talking with Vladimir Putin, at the table today while talking with Vladimir Putin some elements of security trust building which would be part of the equation that's how Emmanuel Macron described it that would allow to to avoid the war and what is important is that Vladimir Putin was very interested in listening to those suggestions and I hope that we will get to know more when both of them will come out to the press after those talks. Well, Galina, talking about no miracles or breakthroughs, I think it's fair to say that NATO has already made its stance very clear that it will not give any security guarantees in terms of limiting further membership, particularly when it comes to Ukraine, for example. So where does this leave President Putin then?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I mean, is there the possibility that Russia could act so as not to be seen as losing face?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, Russia did say that its major concerns were ignored.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Vladimir Putin said that personally.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But many top politicians also said that there were positive things in the U.S. and NATO answers to Russia's security guarantee demands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And if we talk objectively about the interests of Russia's security, actually, there is a whole package of initiatives that was proposed to Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And those initiatives, they actually were something that Russia wanted to talk about before but no one would talk with Russia because of Ukraine and Donbass and what is happening there but now that has changed the US has proposed to Russia to discuss the arms control talks to open the talks on arms control. And this is very important.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And many analysts in Russia, independent analysts, think that actually this is the good outcome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And don't forget, Helena, that Russia has been always saying that it does not plan any war against Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Important points there, Galina Polonskaya.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: As ever, thanks for your insights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, it's not just in Moscow where the push

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: to find diplomatic solution to this crisis is ongoing Kiev is playing host to Germany's foreign minister and Elena Baerbock as well as several other European ministers now Baerbock held talks with her Ukrainian counterpart Dmitry Kuleba and is due to go to the conflict-ridden Donbass region in the southeast of the country on Tuesday. Now, foreign ministers from Austria, Slovakia and the Czech Republic are in Luhansk in eastern Ukraine to look at efforts to overcome Russian hostility in the border region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, let's head straight to Ukraine then, to Avdeevka.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: That's in the east of the country where international correspondent Annalise Borges is standing by for us tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Good to see you, Anneliese. To begin with, Ukraine, once again, the scene of some frenetic diplomacy with European foreign ministers, meeting with the Ukrainian foreign minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: What has been the focus of their attention, Anneliese?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Indeed, four foreign affairs ministers in Ukraine today, an unprecedented diplomatic activity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And their focus has been to see for themselves and to visit places like the area I'm standing right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We're just less than a kilometer from the contact line of a conflict that has been going on here in the east of Ukraine for eight years now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Just a couple of hundred meters away. Separatists have been holding fire against the Ukrainian army. They have been there for the past eight years. These Russian-backed separatists have taken control of pockets of territory that are internationally recognized as Ukrainian. And, of course they have self-declared different institutions and republics in that area and people here in Ukraine people have been meeting over the last few days have been telling me the same thing over and over again that while the entire world has been talking about the possibility of a war they have been dealing with the reality of one for the past eight years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And that is part of the message that the Ukrainian foreign affairs minister, Dmitry Kuleba, will be trying to convey to his European counterparts today and tomorrow, saying that Ukraine wants to be part of the conversation, wants to be part of this diplomatic flur of activities that's been going on uh now all over the world he wants to decide its own future and khalib also said that he wants to convey to his european counterparts some of ukraine's red lines about its territorial integrity but also about its sovereignty when it comes to deciding its own future what alliances will join or will not join in the future and of course one of the issues is also the fact that ukraine refuses to negotiate with representatives from these russian-backed separatists that are currently fighting uh less than a kilometer away annalise on that point of ukrainian sovereignty also when it comes to decision making and messaging you know over the weekend we heard from the u.S. National Security Advisor, Jake Sullivan, saying that Russia was, quote, 70% ready to invade Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So I just wonder, how are those comments going down where you are, when we also know that President Zelensky has also been trying to calm the population and to calm even the markets?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Indeed, it's been a delicate balancing act for Ukrainian authorities over the last few weeks. They have been trying to keep the situation under control, conveying that message, all the while asking the West for help. I asked President Volodymyr Zelensky about that, and he said it was part of his responsibility as a leader not to stir panic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: He needed the population to collaborate, and he needed the economy, as you said, to be stable, even if it was to arm his soldiers in case of a conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So these kinds of what Ukrainian officials here describe as apocalyptic messages from Western officials apocalyptic messages from Western officials don't necessarily help the U.S. and certain U.S.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: officials have been quoted as saying that Kiev, for example, could be invaded in a matter of days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: These are very serious assessments and they don't really help the situation on the ground, according to Ukrainian officials. They say that the West should be cautious when it comes to these assessments, when it comes to releasing that kind of intelligence or at least research. And they say that, of course, while they hope diplomacy can work, they are also very aware of the threat they've been dealing once again with this threat and with this kind of tension for almost a decade now. That's right Annelies Borges our international correspondent on the ground for us tonight in eastern Ukraine as ever thanks Annelies. Well EU's the EU's foreign

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: affairs chief Joseph Borre is in Washington for talks with the Secretary of State Antony Blinken Borre is there for a joint discussion on Ukraine, but more importantly, on alternative energy sources.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Brussels wants to put measures in place to secure Europe's gas supply if it's cut or severely affected. Should Russia decide to stop supplying it if conflict with Ukraine begins?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on those talks, I'm joined by Stefan Korber your news correspondent in Brussels uh Stefan I think it's fair to say that these energy talks come at a crucial time for all countries involved don't they yes Helena that's even an understatement and good evening to you so it's the first meeting of the US-EU Energy Council after a four-year hiatus during the Trump administration and the first meeting during the current Ukraine crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: What can be done if Russian gas supplies to Europe are disrupted?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is a question Brussels is dealing with for several years now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In fact, the European Commission set up contingency plans following the Russian annexation of Crimea. Plans that have been updated over the past months, I was told.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's clear that Europe cannot cope with the gas crisis alone. And here's where the United States comes in for help.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Earlier, I spoke with an energy expert who told me what exactly Washington needs to do now. Take a listen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Two main things the US can do.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The first is to try to put pressure on US suppliers to make sure that as many cubic meters of US LNG, so liquefied natural gas, can go from the US to Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And the second thing they can do is to put pressure on other suppliers of lng such as australia qatar to to try to shift as many bcm of natural gas as possible to europe having in mind that obviously europeans are going to pay the i'm going to pay the market price for that for that natural gas of course this is something the US has been doing for a while now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: For example, the Emir of Qatar has been at the White House with President Joe Biden recently, and the EU Energy Commissioner has intensified negotiations with producer countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The problem is we're talking about a tight global gas market that is based on long-term contracts and even the spot market for immediate delivery has only limited spare capacities available now some countries like norway and algeria both top european importers have said they're already operating at full capacity others have pointed to limited shipment capacity. So it's going to be tough.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And even if the US or Qatar and others manage to produce and supply more to Europe, many experts doubt that this will be enough to cover the lack of Russian gas entirely, Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Certainly a tricky one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Stefan Grobe reporting from Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Stefan, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Certainly a tricky one. Stefan Grobe reporting from Brussels. Stefan, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Chinese tennis star Peng Shui has given her first interview to Western media since claiming that a high-ranking Communist Party official sexually assaulted her. Peng told French sports paper Le Quip that the allegation on social media, which was soon deleted, was all a huge misunderstanding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Tom Hill now reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: all a huge misunderstanding. Tom Hill now reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: China's Peng Shui in happier days before she made and retracted a social media post alleging sexual assault. Now she's told a French newspaper in a closely controlled interview, it's all an enormous misunderstanding. But is that enough of a reassurance about her welfare?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I'm not sure we're able as a sports organisation to make that call.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I think the president was right in saying it shouldn't be for us to judge whether there should be an investigation or not.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: You've seen the words in the interview which she gave to La Keepa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I think we need also to listen to her and we need to read what she's saying.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: As we've also discussed, we've been in contact with her, we remain in contact with her, we've met her in person.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Peng Shui briefly disappeared from public view after the post in November, but has since made a number of appearances at state ceremonial events.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Athletes from across Europe got off to a flying start on day three of the Beijing Winter Olympics. British teenager Kirsty Muir managed to secure her place in the ski big air final and 41-year-old

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: French downhill skier Yoann Clary became the oldest medalist in alpine skiing. Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva also proved that age is just a number breaking records at the tender age of 15 but it was Dutch speed skater Irene Wust who stole most of the headlines becoming the first person to win individual gold medals at five different Olympic Games.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well sports reporter Michael Kern I think it has a fair to say has been glued to the Olympics for us good Good to see you, Michael.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I mean, we've got to start with Irene Wurst because, I mean, to complete compete in five Olympic Games in itself is remarkable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But to take gold at five of them as well is incredible, isn't it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Yeah, and she did it in stunning fashion as well, retaining her 1500 metres, tightening the speed skate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's an Olympic record time as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: She did it in one minute, 53.28 seconds. So plenty of records falling for her personally today. She's retiring next month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's an extending 12th Olympic speed skating medal. She's won as well and a sixth gold within those five games. And also she's racing in the thousand meters as well. So there's still a chance for her to add to that tally as well but incredible achievement and I think it's fair to say she certainly etched her name into Olympic history and I think more importantly has inspired many further future gold medalists and speed skating enthusiasts alike. Well from let's talk about someone who's just at the start of their Olympic journey and that is Kamila Valieva smashing records at just 15 utterly amazing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Yeah, no, it certainly is. And it seems the Russians have got a line of these amazing athletes because the past two Olympic champions were also Russian. Adelina Satnikova, she was 17 at the time. Alina Zagatova was 15. So they're certainly doing well. They had a clean sweep at the recent Europeans as well dominating the sport sport but camilla's performance was incredible because she became the first female figure skater to land a quadruple jump at an olympic game so i can just about jump a little bit let alone four times it was in the team event where the russian olympic committed they already sealed the gold medal ahead of the united states and japan but it was incredible and to really kind of put some icing on the cake as well she did it again later in the routine as well so she certainly underlined her status hot favorite for the women's individual event as well but she certainly so we like to set records I think now it's about four or five records she said every time she's competed to the senior debut which was within the last six months so definitely one to watch absolutely and with such elegance and artistry as well, which really I just found incredible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Let's talk about France's Yoann Clery then, because he claimed a silver medal in the men's downhill at 41 years old.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But how close was he to nabbing that top spot?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So close. 0.1 seconds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And this is what it all comes down to in competitive sport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: 0.1 seconds between that and the gold medal it was a thrilling downhill at the winter olympics as you mentioned there took the silver to become the oldest medalist in alpine skiing and this is what i love it's the human stories when you look into johan he first showed up at the world cup skiing scene 2003 most of his rivals that were in the final today were still on the baby slopes at that point.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's had a 19-year career, 216 starts on the circuit. He's never won, but he's made the podium nine times, competed in four Olympic Games. And guess what? He's topped off with a silver medal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So an amazing career for him. Absolutely. AJ, nothing but a number showed there in Beijing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Michael Kern, thank you so much. The CEO of Spotify has said that the platform will not silence Joe Rogan after clips of the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: podcaster using the N-word resurfaced over the weekend. Matthew and our team in the Cube have been following the story. Helena, Spotify once again in the spotlight for its stance on one of its most popular podcasters and how they say they will not censor Joe Rogan despite a growing backlash.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The singer-songwriter, India Ari, has become the latest artist to join a growing boycott of Spotify after she, on Instagram, released videos of Joe Rogan, where in the past he used the N-word and other racist terms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This is what India Ari had to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I want to be clear, in no uncertain terms, where I stand on this is that he shouldn't even be uttering the word.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Don't even say it under any context. Don't say it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Now, Joe Rogan has responded to this, saying that he hopes it will be a teachable moment for him. Have a listen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: for him. Have a listen. Hello friends. Um, I'm making this video to talk about the most regretful and shameful thing that I've ever had to talk about publicly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Several videos from the Joe Rogan experience podcast have now been removed for racially insensitive language. But amidst all of this, the CEO of Spotify, Daniel Ek has said that he does not believe the platform should be a censor to moderate content.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And he also, in a letter to employees this weekend, once again said that he does not believe that silencing or cancelling Joe Rogan is the answer, despite his very hurtful language.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Daniel Ek also said that Spotify would be making an investment towards music and audio content towards historically marginalised groups. But Helena, the criticism of Spotify is growing, like we have seen for other big tech companies in the past. And criticism is also growing for Joe Rogan himself, with many people who previously backed him, like actor Dwayne the Rock Johnson, also now changing their tune.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: All right, Matthew, following all the reaction and fallout on that story, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, we leave you now with a no comment from Libya's ancient Roman city of Sabratha, which due to conflict in the region is considered endangered by UNESCO.
